Legal_Issue: Whether Teva's counterclaim for indirect patent infringement discloses a reasonable cause of action
Evidence_Assessment: Allegations that Zambon Companies sold gabapentin, leading to importation by Apotex/Torpharm into Canada
Decision_Outcome: Counterclaim not struck; allowed to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: On the party moving to strike to show no reasonable cause of action
Credibility_Factor: Plausibility of allegations at the pleading stage
Legal_Rule: A claim should not be struck unless it is plain and obvious that it discloses no reasonable cause of action
Procedural_Issue: Motion to strike for failure to disclose a cause of action
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; claim allowed to proceed
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Proper procedural posture for motion to strike
Key_Evidence_Considered: Alleged sale of gabapentin by Zambon leading to Canadian importation
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law on indirect infringement
Applicant_Challenge: Zambon Companies sought to strike Teva's counterclaim
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial determination on motion to strike
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to disclose reasonable cause of action
Applicable_Process: Motion practice under Federal Courts Rules
Governing_Rule: Rule 213(3) of the Federal Courts Rules (motion to strike)
